4f9zyUI3loYe1z6lXLip8g.text: I was not impressed - but not by the service like everyone else says.  The food was simply not very good - even the duck!  Everything was VERY greasy, even for Chinese food.I know duck is a fatty meat, so I was expecting that.  But it was cold and not all that flavorful.  For "the best duck in the city" I was completely unimpressedNoodles were greasy and tasted okay for the first few bites then just got weird.  Cantonese Beef (I think) was fine but no better than chinese you would get from one of those street vendors in Camden.  Same with the egg rolls - tasted like the same ones you'd buy in the freezer section and were like sponges of grease.There are a ton of other Chinese places right in the area.... no reason to have to wait around at this one when it gets busy.  I wont be going back.

4mPA2MEscktvI02zq9e_fg.text: I went there with my girlfriend asked for a table for 2 and the man was so ruled that me and the girlfriend just walked out. Not sure what the food was like. DON'T CARE

jygZV32mEKjTN_J94t0xhw.text: Low key and delicious authentic chinese food in an unassuming locale.

BCcLsr40KETijJ4Dx_-O-g.text: DON'T GO THERE!Too expensive, side dishes not really cooked, leaving stomach ache . Waited much too long to be served.Unwilling to pay for the service charge which nobody has to( by law) we were treated and shouted at like stupid tourists byunfriendly and AGRESSIVE staff ,this was my worst London Experience.

cnV5KovFE-qr_YagaiViQQ.text: had the eel and roast duck. yum. wish the place was cleaner and service was better (ok for a chinese restaurant haha) and the food could have been less oily. why do they put so much oil??

CdeLJcmhV47KA9BxpzeRTA.text: The roast duck and the drunken chicken are two of the many dishes which I consider the best London. This is a good place for eating with a group of friends as you can try many more different dishes. This is quite a traditional chinese restaurant with traditional interior. It is advisable to book in advance as the queue is always rally long. Without booking, you might have to wait for about 30-40mins.

hdFfa8vVJy9t2CQrI0qQvA.text: Best cantonese style roast duck in London. The nice layer of fat under the tasty skin just melts in your mouth. Definitely better than the one in Leicester Square. However if you want to have other dishes it's best that you go to Gold Mine which is not far away.

QRXJRPhElVIPfxxpbcVIDA.text: The first chinese restaurant I ate in since I arrived in Uk. I must say it had exceeded my expectations as I thought it would never compare to the ones I had in Malaysia. However, there's usually a long wait and you might have to share your table with others. Not a place for a romantic dinner.

GRAoszjBuBIbSnyNSXLVpQ.text: Used to be famous for its roast duck. We went again recently and find the taste of the roast duck has somewhat changed. I was told by the manager that the main chef has left the restaurant sometime ago and that was the reason for the drop in food quality. Shame. It has now become just a normal chinese restaurant.

IwvneLF85wTF8x5K_qhT0Q.text: The food at Four Season used to be best in London (due to it's famous roast duck). However, after its famous chef left the restaurant ant join another, the quality of food drops. I went there on Sunday for a meal with another 4 friends and ordered 5 dishes to be shared amongst us, the dishes were the ones we usually ordered when we go there. The food is salty, oily, although the service remain to be good. I wonder if it's still worth going despite the chef left for another restaurant.

E-MF16njIK39wurur9f4SA.text: This place has the best duck in London. When I am in this area I will have a meal here. The food is great not only the duck. You can get lots of other chinese dishes too. The prices are reasonable and the atmosphere is good. The people are friendly and service is good too. Occasionally I go there just to get duck as a takeaway for my family for dinner at home. If you want a good meal head over there and have some duck plus try other dishes too.

IyJL8bvoSEP_95j1uBWYJw.text: Not as good as before in my opinion. Used to be really good. Only worth going for the Roast Duck, Char siu, Crispy Pork but other than that, nothing overly special.

Go72VCMUfaMOxUz7s0ZnXw.text: the best roast duck in london!the queues to get in weekend evenings prove that, and many in the queue are chinese nationals, who should be the best judges!this restaurant is so popular, it has recently opened a sister restaurant in gerrard street, china town, soho, which has kept up the great reputation.although all the food is good, the roast meats, ie. duck, roast pork (char siu) and crispy pork are what bring the customers back time and time again!i should know, i have been enjoying the roast meats at the queensway branch for over 10 years now.highly recommendedenjoy!

ouSjiBFuuZD5Nsop5otYdw.text: Why do we put up with dirty carpets and toilets;waiters who don't speak English;incomprehensible bills etc?We went to this place hoping our chinese restaurant experience would be different.We found rude staff,sticky menus,dirty tablecloths,zero help/suggestions of things to try(even when we pointed to dishes at the tables of chinese customers and asked what they were).We ended up with the usual boring,overcooked dry duck and pancakes etc.Then a final bill with Chinese symbols and one number-the total to be paid.Am sure this must be illegal,but our armies of Govt. employees are too busy looking into our dustbins or harassing car owners to do anything else.

2ZbMLL8Y_BrJTQm4I6oigw.text: I recently made my second trip to this restaurant while on a trip to London for a wedding.  Of course I ordered some duck dishes with the people I was with.  Basically, if you come to this place and don't order the duck, you shouldn't be allowed back.  If you don't like duck, try it at this place and see how you feel.  If you still don't like duck, your loss.

eNrI-8csI9nmrP4IhtrkwQ.text: This is the original Four Seasons restaurant - another branch has opened recently in Chinatown. It is famous among the Chinese community for having the best roast duck in town and the long queues snaking out of the door at the weekends attest to that fact. Apparently, their famous roast duck chef left last year but that  doesn't seem to have diminished any of its popularity.Now, just to clarify matters. Roast duck are the birds hanging up for display on the shopfront. Crispy aromatic duck is the deep fried duck starter served with pancakes, cucumber and plum sauce and is a peculiarly English dish - you can't find this in the Far East. Peking duck is another starter which has a much more elaborate preparation including the use of a bicycle pump to separate the skin from the flesh to ensure a crispy finish and is usually served in several courses.Four Seasons is famous for its roast duck and I love watching the chefs expertly dissecting the duck to feed the seemingly never endless queues of eager customers in the restaurant and waiting for takeaway. It fascinates me to watch any expert wield their tool of choice and the way the chefs use their huge meat cleavers to de-bone the duck is amazing. I just stand and watch at the window for ages sometimes.At busy periods, make sure that you leave your name and party size with the waiter just inside the door so you're in the queue for a table. Takeaway is also done in the cramped area just inside the door, so make sure you're not claustrophobic!The service is brisk as it has to be in such a popular place. You're offered the duck on or off the bone, which is fairly unique in my experience - they charge more for de-boning. There is also the usual Ango-Canto fare in a full menu but most people come for duck.So, is it the best duck in London? It's among the best but I find the accompanying sauce a bit too sweet.

C7d80zl-Dp0juu3mwBoiPA.text: This place was highly recommended by just about everyone, and I was a bit hesitant to try the duck since I had duck the previous night and wanted to start my "healthier" eating habits initiative today...BUT i couldn't help myself. As I watched the man in the windo chop the juicy duck, I had to try it..so I did, and it was well worth it. Other than the sumptuous and delectable duck, I ordered the seafood noodle dish, which was AMAZING. The only reason it didn't receive a five-star rating was the simple reason ore: customer service.....service was FAST, but that's about it.

2_4l-mzLd4j8UFDZvusiGQ.text: YEAH! not used to paying so much for Chinese food, but my cousin took me here and SHE paid - so that was cool. But my last meal in London was something a little closer to my ethnic roots - and as it was a cold night, having hot, succulent slices of duck meat paired with stir-fried noodles was quite welcome. The duck here is sublime, and I say this as a person who, in the past, was like, "meh" about duck. Now I find myself thinking, "God that was great duck. Where can I find more duck like that." Highly highly highly recommended - GET THE DUCK.

OR_12WtYY4kGHxp8BbGC7w.text: This is definitely a gem outside of touristy Chinatown. A London resident took me to this place, says it's famous for its roasted duck. We got there and as I expected, there was a queue although I didn't expect to wait an hour for a table since most Chinese restaurants have the ability to move patrons quickly, but I guess it was just the timing. Once we were seated, everything was good. We were attended to immediately. We ordered the duck, some bbq pork, a stir-fry vegetable dish, belly pork claypot and soup. The food came out quickly and everything was very yummy! The duck was definitely worth the wait!

tcsx3UNrQrNfxgg2thS8qg.text: maybe "best" is an exaggeration but i definitely didn't find mine soggy...and i really didn't understand why folks were ordering it drenched in soy sauce.  i think the biggest tell-tale is that both my husband and i were handed chopsticks and the tables who got soy sauce drenched duck were given forks...the negative comments i see are the result of expecting ambiance and fantastic service.  really - a chinese restaurant...let alone a chinese restaurant on queensway?  you want great surroundings and 5 star service, go to mayfair and pay the price.  go to four seasons for a solid, satisfying meal.1/4 duck is perfect for 2.  we got the crispy duck.  we also got the beef with cashew (surprisingly good quality beef!), pei pa tofu (was a bit denser than pearl liang so it just depends on how you like your tofu) and green beans with pork.  -we obviously had to take home some of the food.really good chinese food.  must call ahead because it's small and the line is out the door between 730p and 9p.  once seated and despite the line, they didn't rush us at all.

iOiHD1RBAwSCxkJhh9qxig.text: Many Chinese restaurants in Bayswater think it's smart/OK to be rude. This is one of them. From the surly staff to the off-hand management. They just don't care. After all, there's a whole street of people outside that want to eat. The food is nothing special but it's perfectly edible. But pay Service Charge for the servoce you get? No thanks!

JGOhD6DES6a4L14tO-OvbA.text: Four Seasons. Oft repeated as the "Best place to get Duck in London" I am not that great a fan. I'll start with the fact, I've been here three times, which is probably sufficient to get to know a place enough to right a review. Now, a conumdrum: Q) Why does a restaurant have to have bad service and rude staff? A) It doesn't. This therefore is the starting point that knocks Four Seasons down. Every time, despite a reservation it's impossible to get to the table on-time. Small delays are always fine, but since you often are left standing outside in the cold long ones are not so acceptable. Combined with staff who either don't want to speak English or aren't paid enough to be polite, it's not the nicest experience. This is followed up with the food. Which should be the foundation of any restaurant. We've had the duck and we've had other dishes and despite some reasonably good reviews here we tend to feel a bit let down. Portions are small (especially of duck) for the expensive price and the taste is no more than might be expected at other Restaurants serving duck. After having been in China and being treated to a private event at the Beijing Quanjude Duck Restaurant this place is really far off-the mark. If it's worth paying significantly extra for something only marginally better than other Chinese restaurants then this may be one of the best places for Duck. But that best is not very good for the price. Other dishes were interesting, with some genuine authentic Chinese food. Some of the whole fish dishes are really nice and special, but again portion size might let you down and if that doesn't serving staff forgetting drinks orders, getting the wrong dish and then being rude about it might finish you off. If you want your table disinfected and sprayed when you're still trying to finish due to the next group of people booked too early coming in, also the right place for it. I don't normally like being negative, but I've been to plenty of great Chinese restaurants, with good food, competitive prices and decent staff. See "My Old Place" near Liverpool street for an example.

SJEtii-zFYCAY9cozAJOCw.text: The good:Very nice roast duck.Excellent pak choi / kailan in crab sauceConsistent quality over the 8 years I have frequented this restaurant.The bad:There is always a queue at meal times (though this is a good sign).The staff can be quite surly.

whbsNU8CfweKVZ9TVnAcew.text: I am surprised that Four Seasons received four stars.  I ordered the pea shoots, seafood fried noodles and also the lemon chicken.  The pea shoots were not tender, clearly their useful life had expired.  The seafood fried noodles contained two prawns and two scallops and a ton of soy sauce - it was terrible.  Finally the lemon chicken tasted like it was microwaved.  Very very disappointed.  Finally, the service was poor and waiter was rude, yet we were charged a 12.5% service fee.

OMQUY-_6MNZDgUj2zv4k-Q.text: The best juicy duck (not pancake duck, don't get confused) in London. No booking, just very long queues and the grumpiest door lady in the world. Worth it though. Try the eel in black bean sauce.

PSBaE_ulcYaMq1hhFHiWAg.text: Like most people I find it very difficult to navigate the labyrinth that is Chinatown. Restaurant's could be good, bad or awful and from the outside there is absolutely no way of telling. The general technique I apply is to find a queue and join it. This is how I stumbled on Four Seasons. After a short wait we were directed up a very narrow staircase to what felt like it should be some body's living room. There must have been forty people in this tiny space but the atmosphere was absolutely buzzing because of it. With a reputation for being specialist's in 'Crispy Duck' we felt it would be bad of us not to give it a try. The duck was delicious and everything you would expect from a great Chinese restaurant. Our other course, Kung Po Prawns was also very nice, if a little too sweet for my tastes. If you're ever in the same situation as me and worrying which restaurant to go to in Chinatown, I'd recommend the Four Seasons over any of the others I've tried. Maybe don't take your vegetarian friends though, the meat display in the window might be a bit too much...

8zea_bfCfIemBHFcVX74AQ.text: This restaurant is easy to find, just spot the queue along the street of Chinese restaurant and you'll find this restaurant. This restaurant is always busy with students, tourists and local alike. Used to go there for roasted duck, however recently I find the standard has dropped and would have second thoughts if I ever want to go back for the roasted duck. Service is not great, you need to try hard to get the staffs attention.

_8RYB2tLLl_d2VRu6ZkrZQ.text: Four Seasons is a bit of an institute on Bayswater Road, almost always with large queues forming outside around dining hours. Its most famous for their Roast Duck dish, with a perfectly crisp skin, flavoursome sauce and all at still reasonable prices. The only catch with this place is that it's a very small restaurant and is just generally heaving. Having used to live in the area, I preferred to generally order takeaway since it almost feels like you're being rushed when you're inside given the crowd of people blocking the entrance. Like what you'd think most busy Chinese places are, there's no obvious queuing system and it feels like you have to almost push your way just to get your name down on their system. Still I like to think that their food is sometimes worth the wait although there are many, almost as good places to go around the area. Most of their other dishes are pretty high quality too and would definitely recommend the king prawn chow mein.

fOPnVgiepqqaIc0kh2-Ayg.text: The first time I ever came to London, I ate at the Four Seasons restaurant, and ordered the crispy duck with pancakes. I have since never found a chinese restaurant whose duck matches that of the Four Seasons, so I go back whenever I'm in the area!You can eat in or takeaway - both are busy - but the staff are amazing to watch as they organise both table orders and takeaway dinners.Everything I've ever tried on the menu is excellent quality, delicious Chinese food. Although these guys are the duck experts, so be sure to try it.

Ulc8ASEVkAWe4t3bswv8NA.text: Their roast duck taste and quality have recently changed because the chef that used to cook the ducks had left. So if you are going purely for the roast duck, you may be disappointed. on my last visit, I had to wait for 20 minutes for a table, and i was with a friend. there were groups of 4 to 6 people who came after us, with no bookings and got seats before us. This was because there was bigger tables available and the restaurant cannot justify allocating these tables to 2 people who instead of to bigger groups, as their reasoning is : bigger group-- bigger bill-- bigger profit. We were seated on a 8 seater table with 3 other couples, so hardly a good start to a romantic evening. the food was good, but the roast duck was disappointing. I love the seafood tofu that they make so that makes up for the suck, i guess. But the bill doesnt actually justify the quality of the food nor the service we received.

Tud2IO9EqelWVpXQEk0pjQ.text: What can I say? Used to travel from Oxford to London just to get the duck. You cannot miss it. Of course, as in any other good Chinese place, service is rather weak but as soon as you have the first bite of that addictive duck you won't mind the service at all - it could be served by Seinfeld's Soup Nazi and it would still be the best!

x3og0M2QnLc_RkXnTsryyA.text: I hated this place...Lousy staff, bleh decor..We came in with 6 in our party (Aug 9, 2010).  They stuck us in the dungeon and forgot about us.We ordered a family style dinner.  After the aps, we asked about the rest of our food.  We were told it was coming.  After 20 more minutes and several requests for updates we decided to leave.  (hmmm, all the Chinese families seated around us seemed to get their food quickly...)They then tried to bill us for a bunch of other food we never received, ordered, or even knew about.The discussion turned into a yelling match in the middle of their restaurant after which our server busted out, "I no speak English".  Seriously, you were fine with English up until this point.  Now you don't speak any english when I need to speak to your manager?!?!?Stupid trick...So, the manager took us outside and we further discussed the matter.  Seems like the manager didn't know we made numerious requests for the rest of our food.  The server told him we wanted to skip out on our bill which wasn't the case.  We just wanted to pay what we'd owed.Long story short, we ate down the street...And I made of point of telling ever tourist that was looking at their menu of my story...  Turned away at least 30 people in that 15 minutes I finished up my cig...

qYfR56Ir-yaLL8REUJ4N3g.text: Four Seasons Bayswater? THE WORST SERVICE EVER! Seriously, I've been to many Chinese restaurants in the UK but this is the worst place. The food was just average(roasted duck was a bit too oily and greasy). So if you ask me if I will return to this restaurant again, the answer will be absolutely "NO and NEVER".

LzPV2Ss5nCh541WV9M6iYw.text: I came to Four Seasons with out of town work colleagues for dinner, and I was surprised to see a long queue of people inside and outside the joint.  My colleagues were raving about the duck and apparently, that is the main attraction about the place.  While I'm not a huge fan of duck, I'll still have my fill of confit du canard from time to time.   We ordered various vegetable and seafood dishes, and of course, duck!  One thing I took away from Four Seasons is that it contributed to upgrading my opinion of Cantonese cuisine in London.  Every dish we ordered there was delicious and well prepared and service was quick.  I recommend Four Seasons for those who want to brave some Chinese cuisine outside Chinatown.

ejAOmEVzrsDm8pYMOjMxqQ.text: Poor service with service charge include in the bill. Good food so give and take . Not my cup of tea . Chinese food at the others r good as the same.

JWJARqYYhe3xBY7mJDIYvQ.text: What is this bullshit about the best duck in the world?  FT, go to CHINA AND HAVE A DUCK ANYWHERE IN BEIJING OR GUANGZHOU.  Or even....try San Francisco or LA.  The duck is good.  But I could find duck just as good selling for 5-7 pounds (WHOLE DUCK) in the Bay Area.  I'm a spoiled San Fran brat because we Californians actually have good Chinese food unlike ANYWHERE IN EUROPE WHY WHY WHY.  Ugh.  I've given up on London.  I thought that at least London would have decent Chinese food, but no.  It's expensive.  And the best I can find is "ok"...like Four Seasons.  Basically, this place is like any cheap, small hole in the wall Cantonese restaurant you can find lined up on the streets of Oakland California....except double the prices (not EVEN taking into account the exchange rate). You know, this is the place you go to get a good beef ho fun after drinking too much in SF.  Incidentally, Four Seasons makes the best beef ho fun I've had in the UK....which is sad because how hard is it to make beef ho fun?  Not very (which is why every hole in the wall in SF can...)3 stars because for London, it's good.

KXVoTQDs0nwCu62ewH7plw.text: Great Chinese restaurant in London. Among if not the best for dinner. have to try the boneless duck

iZifqVppFO7_Acqbj7JLrA.text: I just don't get it! I really don't understand why people go on about how good the roast duck is here. I have had roast duck everywhere and I just don't get it!I popped in for a quick lunch and had to wait for about 5 mins before anyone even took any notice of me and it wasn't even busy.I quickly ordered a plate of duck rice, a portion of gai lan veg and a pot of tea  nice and simple, right?What I got was a portion of burnt, fatty roast duck (with feather follicles still attached to parts of the skin  yuk!) and the sauce that came with it was so sweet I thought they had poured sugar syrup on instead. I have to find the bits of rice that hadn't soaked the sauce in before I could eat it. The meat itself was just about OK but had tough bits.The veg was overcooked and limp, sitting in a small swamp of green-ish water. And service with a frown :-(At least they didn't screw up the tea!!A huge disappointment.

a8MVdb9R08gszMnptbeICA.text: I thought I couldn't find roast duck/chicken better than what I can find in NY until I stumbled upon Four Seasons.  Funny because you think of the 5 star hotel initally and wonder what to expect.  It is a no frills - don't bother to expect good service or decor but certainly the roast duck delivers.  Other things to try - char siu pork, aubergine hot pot, and crispy duck pancakes.  Definitely make reservations if you plan on having a relatively large group.

ZiylAIxKXDZwXZBj52ch3A.text: I went to Four Seasons to try the roast duck, which the FT described in a review a couple of weekends ago as possibly the best in the world.  I haven't tried all the roast duck in the world (although I'm working on it), but this duck was indeed, by any standard, stupid-delicious.  The skin was thin and crispy, the meat tender, and it came smothered in a perfectly-sweet, not-too-salty soy sauce.But that's not all.  The other dishes we ordered were great too.  The hot and sour soup was actually pretty spicy, which it almost never is anywhere else, and it was full of little treats and prizes that you don't usually find in there, like shrimp and fish cakes, along with the usual veggies and shredded pork.  The house fried noodles and sizzling bean curd with mixed seafood were similarly full of goodies, and all the seafood was really fresh.I just finished the rest of the leftover duck for dinner, and am happy.

MWjOI8hpzXawi2CCI3V0Dg.text: Best duck in the world?  Are you actually kidding me?  No way.  Not at all.   It doesn't even rank top ten.  Or top three down that street for that matter.  Skin was soggy, flavour was bland and mildly salty, soy sauce was... soy sauce.  Letdown.  Asides from the duck, it was okay.  Highlights include paper baked boneless pork chops (which were described as not being for white people.. perhaps white people might think the baking paper was rice paper??) and sizzling beef.  I don't know... I feel like all English Chinese food tastes the same, regardless of the restaurant.  Maybe they've all adapted to English tastes?  I was really thirsty afterwards with a bit of a headache, so I'm going to assume there's quite a bit of MSG.We thought we were going to be nine people, and they sat us at a large table.  After a few calls, we found we were going to be seven, and since the restaurant was filling up pretty fast we thought we'd be considerate and asked to move to the smaller table nearby.  The waitress replied, "You'd better.  Or else they kill you."  It sounded like a forceful serious threat WITH THE MOST DEADPAN FACE EVER.  We were scared at the time, but spent the rest of the evening laughing about it later.Despite the restaurant filling up, and lots of people queueing, they didn't rush us AT ALL.  We took as much time as we wanted and none of the waitstaff were hovering around us.  I really appreciated that.  Extra star for that.

yKZDbMrIk1jT_iSVXxlsiQ.text: Roast duck is a queen. Char siu and Crispy pork are just the knights. Can't live without them!! So I recommend these 3 classic combinations.

IABA1TDEUWk0LztX4QiDcQ.text: Seriously? Apart from some good duck this was a lousy dinner. Average Chinese food, dirty tables that wobble and pushy brusque wait-staff.We beat the feverish queue by booking ahead and were seated instantly. Time to relax and chat with old friends? Nope - time to be brow-beaten into ordering ASAP. TIME TIME TIME. No Time To Spare!Starters of poor spring rolls and mediocre soft-shell crab were forgiven by lovely crispy aromatic duck pancakes, but nothing that we couldn't get at somewhere more civilised. Pancakes gone and we were left with braised aubergine, rice and veg that looked like regular canteen schlop. Not the appetising far east delicacies I felt promised by such a high Yelp score.As well as the hurried, slapdash and loud atmosphere, another Four Seasons classic is the random bill at the end, with no breakdown of costs, just Chinese scribbles. Beware that you optional service charge has already been added to this without warning.There are some plus points. It's cheap. The full-time orange slices are amazingly juicy and sweet. And best of all, the table changes when you move from starter to main and mains to bill are a work of art. Two wait-staff in unison will transform your table in seconds like a Ferrari Grand Prix team doing a tyre-change.

vFG1dSicS5LL7m0ineJchA.text: I've been trying to find an authentic and affordable Chinese restaurant since I first arrived in London; and this place takes the cake!What we ordered:(2 people, yes we are fat pigs) Gai lan with oyster sauce - I love this veggieRoasted duck (very succulent, flavourful, but a bit on the fatty side)Sweet and Sour pork - okayFried pork dumplings - filling was yummy but the skin was too doughyService was ok, not too bad for Chinese restaurant. Lots of chinese people eating here which is always a good sign. Will come back again, but maybe order less food. =)

1Dmkem00fq3Bm5dXkoPA6g.text: YUM. YUMMY. YUM. YUM.A total Roast Duck Win.  Except it was a little burnt on a couple of pieces.  The duck was succulent and super crispy skin.I found the waitress who served me very friendly, but it was very quiet and she was complaining of bad business due to the snow, so I am going to go back for more today!  Hopefully my roast duck obsession can keep them in business! (but no good for my diet!)Unfortunately they don't have soured plum sauce, which to me is a Cantonese roast duck milestone, so minus one star for that.  Oh and no peanuts.  Poop.

ruo-NuLTOxm3LuP0qws9Jw.text: Make sure you reserve a table; it'll save you a lot of time. The place was packed out when my friends and I went there. We'd booked a table and had to wait for about 10-15 more minutes, and even then we leapfrogged the people in the queue that hadn't booked in advance, so I don't know how long they had to wait...Like everyone says, the roast duck is great. I think it's a stretch to say it's the best in the world though. That honour would have to be reserved for a place in Beijing (you can never replicate something in another country perfectly). However, it certainly is a great roast duck, is better than many places I ate at in China and could well be the best in London.Plus of course, it's authentic chinese food, not british-adapted chinese food :). We need more places like that in London.

nC0A7LGBoFvb7rCv0fhg9A.text: The Four Season Restaurant in London's Queensway don't mess around when it comes to roast ducks. Just across the street from the Bayswater tube stop, this Chinese restaurant gives out the roast duck aroma that you can smell from a block away. If you don't know restaurant's exact location, just look for the long lines outside the restaurant. Lines continue to form even on those cold London winter days. That tells you how seriously yummy the ducks are. If you go, order the roast duck, BBQ pork and a dish or two of stir fried vegetables and that's all you need. The ducks are roasted to perfection with a thin layer of crispy skin that I wish I could just skim off the skin and eat it like potatoes chips. The meat is still juicy and moist and it is served hot with the most addicting duck sauce that the chef saved from the ducks drippings. Drizzle the sauce over rice and you'll find yourself going back for seconds and thirds. Is a simple Chinese restaurant, but the food is authentic, very delicious and the price tag is modest. And like typical Chinese restaurants, the table service is spotty and you have to speak over all the noises when the restaurant is full. But I don't go there expecting Savoy's level of services, I go there because I love their roast ducks.

ihPc3Wh7phB4fDrnidvalw.text: One of the best places in London for roast duck! The portion we had today was juicy, succulent, tasty... Couldn't ask for more. I like it here because it us busy and bustling. The food is always nice - my favourites are the roast duck (obviously!), the Japanese tofu with enoki mushrooms, Cantonese sizzling beef and Chinese broccoli with prawn cakes. Mmm... The downside of a busy place is that service can be chaotic and you may have to wait a while for a table. Today was fairly pleasant as we didn't have to wait too long. In addition, while the staff wanted to move us to a smaller table to allow a larger group to sit down (which in my opinion, is just terribly efficient), they were polite and apologetic about it and it was no hardship to us. The manager also came along to (indirectly) compliment my coat, which did cause the rest of my group to question their own style sense!I like coming here because turnaround is quick, the food yummy and there is no fuss.

WVWL1YMsTd0vi1Yn3zaSBg.text: The number of south-east Asian people in a Chinese restaurant is usually a pretty good indicator of the quality. Last time I tried to go to the Four Seasons I couldn't get in because there was an hour long wait to get in. Good sign. This time we were lucky and managed to snag a table almost immediately, despite a substantial line starting to develop. This place is famous for its roast duck so we immediately ordered that, along with some hot and sour soup, beef with green onions, sizzling prawns, and some fried rice. I ordered a Tsing Tao beer which I was delighted to have delivered to me in a can with one of those old school pull top tabs. Awesome. The soup came quickly enough and was hot and delicious. The entrees shortly followed and were also absolutely fantastic. Nice fresh vegetables, tender meat, flavorful prawns. The duck took a while and we had to ask where it was but the place was absolutely packed so I can't blame them for taking a little longer to bring their house special. All I have to say about their duck is this: Stop whatever you're doing, and go. Now. Their duck is like nothing I have ever had before. I'm not sure what they do with it, and frankly I don't care. I'm pretty sure there's some addictive substance or something involved because I just couldn't stop eating it. Crispy on the outside, tender and juicy in the middle. Absolutely perfect. The service was quick and a bit stilted but as I said, they were jam packed. They did well, all things considered. A truly impressive experience, one which I will be repeating many, many times.

photos.caption: Photo of Four Seasons - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Four Seasons - London, United Kingdom

lFJnecslJ6bC439Fn1tgwg.text: Great Roast duck, Great BBQ pork Awesome veggies. I have been going here every time I go back on vacation. We usually rent an apartment in the Kensington area, by tradition our first dinner is usually here. The food is consistently good. Service could be better, I don't blame the waiters, this place is packed and can get very NOISY at times.Sometimes the queue spills onto the street.As much as I look forward to my next vacation in London, I look forward to my first dinner at Four Seasons.

LV5c7ygkPbIxNRpCoFPjTQ.text: As we left the underground station and headed to our hotel, we couldn't help but notice the crowd of people standing outside this restaurant.We come to find out they're known for their roast duck; so, we decided to give them a shot.  As the family waited outside, I walked up and down Queensway looking at all the shops and knickknacks.  About 40 mins later we were finally seated.We ordered the Aromatic duck as well as the Roast duck.  Both were just OK.  I prefer the Roast duck in Los Angeles.  The skin is crispier and the flavor is all around... better.The service -- although fast, wasn't that great... but what can you expect in a Chinese Restaurant.

1m6h6ezGcFffLOVlrwa2bA.text: Got off to a good start with the Hot & Sour soup. Then had the overrated duck with a side of egg fried rice. Nothing special about the duck and would have liked it better if it wasn't soggy. The wait staff here has an attitude problem for a restaurant that is okay at best. Really didn't like getting an un-itemized bill with just an amount to pay. Lots of local Chinese go here.  Let them have it and go down the street to Royal China. Better food,staff and service.

photos.caption: Photo of Four Seasons - London, United Kingdom. Duck
Photo of Four Seasons - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Four Seasons - London, United Kingdom

-NzswkdSHfl-F-di25lLsQ.text: Four Seasons Chinese restaurant on Queensway attracts often long queues of Chinese visitors, expats, local Chinese and other community and Asian students craving for some good home style food. The atmosphere in the restaurant is, with large round family tables, lots of buzz, people everywhere, and sort of Hong Kong style. Service is very efficient but everything besides friendly. This really doesnt matter, it makes it feel even more authentic. (at least to me) Check this out on a Sunday lunch time, before 12.00 and see the mountain high piles of roast duck, char sui pork, crispy pork belly and other roast meats, which are the speciality and reason to go there, piled in the front window. It is not the place where you take a timid, fragile just got to know her girl on a first date because she will be traumatised, shocked and won't eat anything, but with a group of experienced foodie friends who have been abroad at least once in a life, a good Sunday lunch experience.

photos.caption: Photo of Four Seasons - London, United Kingdom

3G9-LZgHjLxhtu0KOXNkcQ.text: Duck duck duck!  We had two if that tells you anything.  And between 3 people (including 2 girls) and a side of crispy pork.  I highly recommend and it will now be a staple for me to visit each time I'm in London.  We got there about 6:00pm and that appeared to be the magic time.  Any time after that and the crowds pile in.  I've had duck many places in my life, abroad, in the States (including SF) and this is definitely at the top of my list.  Maybe not the very top, but super close!  Just do it.

nLyIfL-0EEaVEW8wVbZvjg.text: Verdict: OMG YES!Pros:- The Best aromatic dock.- The Best roast duck.- The BBQ rib and pork.- The price.Cons:- Service. Food/check/beverage will come in what ever order it wants when it wants.- The mama-san actually does give a good scare to lesser used to Asian restaurant culture and more timid Northern Europeans costumers!- Sometimes too noisy.- Ambiance.

XjHdVMI8MIGG2Ucsb2JQHw.text: Very very bad attitude waiter！He shout at us with insulting words for no reason！！Never come if you want to lose you appetite before eating.服务员态度太差！！！！明明订了位，进去后莫名冲着还没坐下的我们大喊大叫：到门口来等，我叫你到门口等着你就去门口等着！什么态度，请字不会说啊！说他没职业道德，他还回说：道德，你有道德么。你认识我们么就没道德。完全不懂待客之道，还说：你认清楚这里不是中国，是英国，装什么装，全世界有礼待客都通用好么！转脸就对白人嬉皮笑脸，真恶心。胃口都倒光了！

-b1IqITlNYxQ9zn73jbB5g.text: Remember the episode of Seinfeld - yes, I'm dating myself - where they're waiting for a table in a Chinese restaurant...well, it's sort of like that. The restaurant is small with mostly 8 person round tables, so it's also jammed packed. They have all the BBQ'd ducks in the front window and watching them debone a duck is amazing - I'm talking 30 seconds start to finish with a huge cleaver. It's worth the price of admission. The food is also excellent, albeit with spotty service that requires you to be a bit more engaged in making things happen. Don't expect a friendly welcome and how do you do - it's all business with a 'you ready to order', but that's what makes it fun. Oh yeah, don't expect a quiet dinner for two - it's better for a larger group that's in the mood for fun. As for recommendations, you can't come to a place that can filet an entire duck in seconds without having any. It's worth it. I also love the crispy pork belly and the spare ribs are great. I also enjoyed the bok choy and the hot and sour soup with a bit of English flair - peas and tiny shrimp. Overall, everything looks good here and I look forward to my next visit.

cyle46FJzF0NVO746JAywA.text: One has to travel outside of London's touristy Chinatown district to get decent Chinese food. I did so with my hunt for decent barbecued meats and saw good Yelp reviews here.It gets 4 stars bc:- it's claim to fame, their roast meat special (roast pork, pork w fried skin and roast duck) combo is to not too shabby.- I didn't experience Asian on Asian discrimination, which happens very often. I actually spoke to them in Cantonese to try this and was treated ok-well, and they even took time to say goodbye to me and didn't try to rush me when I was there alone, hogging up a table by myself on a Sunday around 1pm. (A busy time)- they try to proactively manage the crowds and try their best to fairly seat everyone based on when they come in.- fast service.- easy to get to, located on the Central line, one stop east of Nottinghill GateI have a mixed view to their claim to fame. Their roast duck is not the most banging thing I have ever eaten. Far from that, it is average. The skin was also not the greatest, I don't really eat skin too much but did it here to give an accurate feedback. However, their roast pork is banging! The sauce they serve on the barbecued meats is on the sweet side, but goes very well with this assortment.They do offer you a side of chili oil which is surprisingly also on the sweet side,but I actually found it to be very nice and dashed that on my entire dish.I can't rate the other foods,but why try anything else than this place's name to fame?Note: Everything is relative, so I'm not going to rate this based on other food I've had say in HK or other countries. But to date the best duck I have ever had is actually located in Philadelphia, PA called "Sang Kee Duck House". They have locations near the University of PA and Chinatown.

photos.caption: Photo of Four Seasons - London, United Kingdom. Their claim to fame: roast duck, roast pork and pork w fried skin.

xeoL0rmsDofp8QbIGjt6Dg.text: We both ordered the bbq plates and the portions were generous. Meats were lean and flavorful.We tried the Roast Duck, Char siu, and Crispy Pork. Ambiance is typical chinese restaurant. Nothing fancy and possibly not very clean...but clean enough.

Zhm4Vh4YPFcQmrdrLQlnyw.text: some of the best roast duck and pork in a busy, packed Chinese restaurant near many hotels. The place was packed with regulars who come for the duck. We had to queue and got great tips o what to order.

photos.caption: Photo of Four Seasons - London, United Kingdom. the delicious duck being chopped up for dinner

hl-QsZii3yts3o_TStlVsA.text: Hmm Chinese food in London? It's not bad. Probably as authentic as I've seen in Europe. Very good meats here.

QWm_jJhslNGhjfNuVpOv7A.text: I've been fortunate enough to stay near the Bayswater station both times that I've been to London and by "fortunate" I mean being super close to the Four Seasons restaurant!My friend introduced me to Four Seasons during my first visit and I was totally blown away by their amazing roast duck and pork. The meat here is moist and delicious and not overly fatty at all. I've had my fair share of duck around the world and Four Seasons is by far the best that I've ever had.  I'm not sure if they made a deal with the Devil to make it taste so good, but whatever they did I'm not complaining.My favorite dish here is the boneless roast duck over boiled egg noodles with their yummy duck sauce/drippings. My second favorite is their salt & pepper pork chops and lastly their sliced roast pork with a delicious layer of crackling on the outside.  I've only scratched the surface of their menu, but I intend to come back here every time I'm in town. It's definitely worth a try if you love duck and are in the London area!On a side note, to the reviewers that complain about service, you've obviously never been to many authentic Asian restaurants. I've been here eight times so far and they've always been courteous and attentive, even when super busy. No the service won't leave you feeling all warm and fuzzy inside, but that's really not how it works in Asian culture. Service is usually quick and straight to the point and what some may consider curt is really just the norm. Please get your head out of your arse and do us all a favor by not taking up a seat at this wonderful restaurant.

iQy_eD6bbZDsCwkTJHQQsw.text: Had a short night in London with a couple of guys from work who love and will ferociously demand nothing but the best Chinese dishes, regardless of where they would find themselves at any moment of time. Word got around with the velocity of a lightning bolt to my colleagues about this place in Chinatown, and the results were tantalizing. We ordered the roast duck main dish, along with some mysterious pink shriveled-up morsels of beef. The Panda Express-look threw me off however, as these little treats hit my taste buds with fast oral appreciation and a smile. As well, the duck slipped with slight trepidation between my chopsticks initially, but its slightly salty juices made me at ease once it arrived at its destination. In addition, the cooked 'shrooms with peanut bits and saucy asparagus made me smile, knowing that a *relatively* healthy meal was being consumed. For any of you staying away from carbs, you would be proud. Don't hate on me, I work in I.T!The only slightly down mark was that it took a huge effort to gain the waitresses' attention on a couple of occasions. But that did not deter me from savoring some delicious Daffy with his friends, green sprouts and, *ignorance alert* small Chinese tortilla.

photos.caption: Photo of Four Seasons - London, United Kingdom. Duck with accessories @ Four Seasons

LfTM04IEHVM2z3yoFrv-tg.text: Not as nice as  the other places on the same street. Food is mediocre at best, oily and not particularly flavorful. Duck we had was very fatty. I recommend ordering from eslewhere for half the price.

X1_ZqnusZc4NUL_8g8XqOw.text: One of the best cantonese roast duck I ever had. And that is saying a lot, since I am comparing it with Hong Kong, SF and Vancouver.  This is not your peking roast duck though. (They have that on the menu too)

rb8kMi7_cgHeEq4FrPA6TQ.text: Ordering takeaway over the phone was a struggle, but worth it. The pork crispy spring rolls are some of the best I've had. The two BBQ meats over rice are great- get duck and crispy pork belly. The duck is phenomenal!!

5wT3ga-mCaSCRIMyKkZVnA.text: Got Duck?So this particular place is a Chinese restaurant runned by Malaysian Chinese. Not sure what the difference is, but the food is pretty legit.  There are a few Chinese restaurants on the same street, but chose this because it recevied better reviews on Yelp.  I wasn't sure what to get since I was in a hurry and decided to have a 4 course meal. The best part about our meal was the crispy duck, which was super official. I also recommend the crispy beef which I was very delicious. Comparing to my American Chinese restaurants I noticed that the food here was very good with less grease. Depending on what you get you can get a meal for around £10-£20.Overall this place is legit and recommend to people looking for some sit down Chinese food.

7ca2x__43OYFlmnw6Inj4w.text: Reading all the positive reviews, I had set my hopes high for this place. There are quite a few asian restaurants on Queensway, which is usually a good thing (Brick Lane being a notable exception). I got there around 6:30 on a Wednesday, and the place was about half full. The clientele was about evenly split between Asians and tourists (with possibly some overlap between the two groups). I was quickly seated at a table right next to the door. I hate being next to the door especially if there are people waiting for a table, but since there were plenty of free tables, I thought it wouldn't be a problem.The duck gets prepared in the front next to the door, mostly so that people could see it from the street. It's clearly their specialty. However, the menu is huge, so no worries if duck is not your thing.I was thinking of getting the sliced duck, and asked the waitress whether it came with rice. The exchange went almost verbatim like this: -Excuse me, may I ask you a question about the sliced duck dish?-WHAT? WHAT QUESTION?-Does it come with rice?-NO RICE! RICE? ORDER SEPARATE!Yeah, I put her responses in caps for a reason. She *was* yelling.I decided to get the fish ball soup and sliced pork with fried noodles, partly because I'm cheap and partly to spite the rude waitress. The fish ball soup lacked any flavor and the fish balls were rubbery. I was pleasantly surprised by the portion size of the sliced pork noodles, made me feel at home in the US for once. However, despite what one of the reviewers said, the noodles were literally swimming in grease. I've had my fair share of cheap greasy Chinese food, but this was beyond anything I'd ever seen. Even with all the grease, the flavor was lacking, and it was at best average.After asking for the check, I noticed a note on the wall saying that there is a £10 credit card minimum, Also, if you have a swipe card (basically any American credit card) they require a passport or a drivers license. My order was supposed to come out to £9, but it looks like they added a service charge, or maybe they charged for the glass of tap water--no way to tell b/c the bill was all handwritten in chinese characters.By the time I was leaving the restaurant all tables were full, and the line started to build up, so plan to come early if you don't want to wait for a table.Perhaps the duck is as good as people say. As for the rest of the menu, it's subpar, and be ready for some rude service.

OXkD5fxLsBh8wZ_DP8YvLg.text: Very good: *Peking duck ( not the tortia wrap )*House daily special soup.* other chef specialtistServices great, Seating is little tight.Price is acceptable.

cmDGPsD1maUOKuZHA9sL1w.text: My review is based on experience from a few years ago...hope things haven't changed.The roast duck is splendid with the chinese broccoli.

LLyDzlVmA4XJEKJtbGjxoQ.text: Get the 3 combination of barbecue meat over rice. Choose anything really. It's simple but wow is it good. We were there late, so we only got the barbecued pork and barbecued duck. Ideally, get the barbecued duck, crispy pork belly, and spare ribs. I have to go back.

v6ib7ReWzRKwPvVFrFO9Ww.text: if you try to search for world best roasted duck on the internet, this place sure to pop up in the results. So even though i am not into duck, I thought i might give it a try, afterall it is world best roasted duck, how bad can it be!We ordered the wonton mee soup and roasted duck and char siew along with their home-made soya bean. Gosh, the wonton served were hot and juicy, the broth was awesome too. Then the important roasted meat dish came and oh boy, i was speechless. My best friend who was with me know that i am not really into meat, but this time i am totally digging into the meat! You got to try it if ever you are in london!

ibHr7DDQ5OHkItqyz3-9VA.text: Best duck I've ever had. Amazing sauce. The other food is excellent also. This is instantly clear as the restaurant is packed with all sorts of people in stark contrast to the half dozen other Chinese restaurants on Queensway. I also think it's completely comparable with the best Chinese food I've had in China and in the US.Most importantly, it met with the approval of my Chinese parents who now don't want to eat anywhere else in London except there...

SVKDlnrNFjuO5vkn1UdX5Q.text: I have been to Four seasons so many times, and I have never been surprised to find a queue of people outside and there is only one reason for this, the duck in this place is second to none, so succulent and tasty. Writing this is even making my mouth water. It honestly is delicious. However, in contrast, the service in this place is terrible, the staff make no qualms in letting you know that once you have finished your food (in my case it is always the duck), they want you out. It's a struggle for them to smile but even in me knowing this, I still go back, as so many do. The duck is out of this world.As for the décor, there is nothing special inside, just tables and chairs. It is a small restaurant, but I have heard that they will be expanding as there really is a demand for it.Simply, this is the greatest tasting duck I have ever had. I had a lot of duck growing up as my dad once had a shop on the edge on Chinatown, and I had it for lunch many a time, so I know what a good duck is. Thumbs up, 10 out of 10, go Four Seasons. My advice would be to go in a large group so that the staff do not give you looks to hurry you out.

photos.caption: Photo of Four Seasons - London, United Kingdom. Duck, mmm

atNBxqetlpNIcKhnYfTReg.text: I went here for lunch..one of the best chinese restaurant..i ordered the 3 platter combination.. you have to order the roast it is super delicious..CONCLUSION = RECOMMENDED!!

photos.caption: Photo of Four Seasons - London, United Kingdom

QoO5QUHOS7S5iK8pXD9EMA.text: The roast duck is a must order. The ribs and roast pork too dry and hard to chew. Many were there for their duck. So just stick to this, you can't go wrong.

photos.caption: Photo of Four Seasons - London, United Kingdom

OPfwoDmgm3yV4gB6DEJZlw.text: One of the best Chinese restaurants along Queensway in Bayswater. One usually sees people queuing patiently to get in. The good menu is full of delicious and reasonably-priced items, and the service is good and fast.

01sAu836Xpf-mv8n33jbLA.text: This is extremely important before I provide my review.  I want you to order the correct duck.  Order the Cantonese Roast Duck.  NOT the Aromatic Crispy Duck.  The Aromatic Crispy Duck does not exist in the Chinese world and it is a westernised deep fried duck like anything else that Westerners love to eat.  I see a lot of people ordering the wrong version of the duck.  The pictures that I have posted here are the ones you want to order.  Not the one which looks crispy / deep fried.  Continue...If you are ever in need of a juicy, fatty and flavourful Cantonese roast duck, this is the only place to go.  I probably have been to Chinese restaurants around the world and the roast duck here is still world class and best.  I want to say it is only my opinion but I think a few others say so too.  I haven't tried most of the Chinese food as most of the time I am here, I am just after the famous duck.  Order half of it with a steamed rice.  Hell, just order the whole duck!  The sweet and salty soya sauce gravy goes along with it really well.  You need the steamed rice to cut through the fat.  You can order it with bones like how the Chinese likes it or deboned.  Although that said, I have been told off before during a peak time that I couldn't order it deboned as they won't have enough time.  When you arrive go straight in past the queue if there is one and put your name down on their list with the person packing or preparing the food at the front of the restaurant.  They will call you once they have a table for your party.  However, I just have a word of warning for those who are new to this place.  In most Asian countries, the restaurants lack customer service.  It is the same here.  Expect poor customer service with no smiles and rude head 'maitre d's who will take your order.  It depends on their mood you know.  They will only sit you once all your parties have arrived so make sure you get all your parties in before you ask for a table or you will get scolded.  They are the best you know.  If you don't like it, there is the door.  You may leave anytime.  It is not like they have no other customers waiting in line.  Lol.  That said, please look beyond the customer service for the food quality.  When I say it is the best, it is the very best.  It is also extremely good value.  Half whole duck for £13.80 and whole duck for £23.80.  Even if you go to the finest restaurant in London, they will be more expensive than these best ducks.  Go ahead, buy the whole duck, go home and indulge!  I urge you guys to come.

photos.caption: Photo of Four Seasons - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Four Seasons - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Four Seasons - London, United Kingdom

DQj4VaMcZK3hy5vqyM5yiQ.text: Got here right at opening time, so we were the third party to be seated. Excellent, excellent Cantonese roast duck. Order boneless, with a bowl of rice and you're good to go. Duck is super juicy and plump, and the secret sauce that comes with it is delicious. My husband and I went to Chinatown back in NYC 3 days after coming here, and our ducks here are bony and dry :( Service here isn't great, but they're efficient enough and I got to practice my Cantonese, so I'm happy.

GAAn8HvzozRNiIZXU6h8ug.text: I came here for dinner with a few friends when I was in London. I have been here for dinner a couple times now.There was a bit of a wait, but I expected this since we were a party of 5 people. They got us in as soon as they could.We started off with the crispy duck, which I must say, was excellent! The crispy duck is the reason why we come to this restaurant. It has great flavor, moist, and is crispy on the outside. The vegetables, wonton wrappers, and sauce that comes with it goes great with the crispy duck. We also started with the crispy wontons filled with fish. These were certainly interesting. They weren't really my thing because I didn't expect there to be fish in them, but they were interesting to try. For dinner, I got pork noodles. This was pretty good. The portions were very generous.I thought that all staff members were polite and nice, but the service was not so great. A couple of times we asked for more water and more wonton wrappers and never got them. We had to try and track down the servers. As far as price goes, it was fair for London. The restaurant was clean, but very crammed. The tables are very close together, so you have to move your chair whenever someone wants to get out. Overall, EXCELLENT crispy duck (highly recommend), fair prices, and nice staff but could have more attentive service.

photos.caption: Photo of Four Seasons - London, United Kingdom. Pork noodles
Photo of Four Seasons - London, United Kingdom. Crispy duck (excellent!)
Photo of Four Seasons - London, United Kingdom. Vegetables and sauce served with crispy duck

xVVtDo5QDDhF95-6X1vAzw.text: I love this place and especially the crispy duck.  I believe that's what they are know for.  There's always a queue at this place so either eat an early or late dinner.  We always get the crispy duck and the crispy shredded beef.  The BBQ duck is also very delicious and so is the pork belly.  You can actually order a three meat combo dish and have all these to try if you wish.  A bit of a sampler dish really.  The beef cooked in a hotpot is another favorite of mine as well as the Kai Lan with garlic sauce.  Every time I come back to London I make dinner here a priority.  The service is pretty typical of a Chinese restaurant... Bad.  But the food makes up for it!

photos.caption: Photo of Four Seasons - London, United Kingdom. Crispy duck
Photo of Four Seasons - London, United Kingdom. Shredded beef and BBQ plate sampler
Photo of Four Seasons - London, United Kingdom. Kai Lan and shredded beef

KZeZVZ6vDCN_jNLEEs2acw.text: I was there about 6pm , got a place to seat... i had some pork dish with vegetable and fried rice..food was great. I am sure to visit that shop again..

pg2s2xMHlCtZf9TVeFhL3Q.text: Legit.Came here at 9 pm on a Sunday, there was a short wait.Roasted duck (Cantonese style) was very good. Fatty, crispy skin, full of flavour. It's a little bit greasy, but tasted really good if you don't over dose. Crispy pork was ok, it wasn't very well presented (looks nothing like the photo). Too much meat, not enough skin. It's a very authentic Cantonese bbq restaurant. It's quite popular so expect to wait for a bit if you visit during rush hour. There are also two branches in Chinatown.

photos.caption: Photo of Four Seasons - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Four Seasons - London, United Kingdom. Roasted duck

e1eXai8AMZFhCsGcQe_6nw.text: My friend who lived in London for 4 years recommended this restaurant in Chinatown and I'm glad we took his advice!They had a variety of dishes from vegetarian dishes to meat, which all came in generous portions. I would recommend the Chinese mushroom with stewed seasonal vegetable and of course, pecking duck! It can get pretty busy during peak time (we waited for ~45 minutes) so make sure you arrive earlier! Tip: You can ask for no MSG!

1afLGU5NT6U6duwTSastyg.text: Sooooo... I know it's all about duck duck duck here and yes, the duck is truly delicious but what I definitely have to point out in Four Seasons are their soups. Me and my friend have absolutely felt in love with them and now we go to Four Season just for a cup of soup. I always order Crab meat and Sweetcorn and hers is Hot and Sour both of them equally great, depends on your taste.Last time we had a bigger budget to work with so we also ordered some shrimps and beef in black beans sauce and that was really tasty too.Service can be nice or rude, it's a lottery to be honest and also, you might have to queue cause it's so good.

Y_5RdJFKAY8TvymoXQH4vA.text: This place definitely has some of the better peking duck available in the world. Unfortunately though it comes at ta cost of long waits (I avoided it but the next group had quite a long wait), inconsiderate service, and it's most definitely overpriced. But, since it's all about the food for me I can't not recommend Four Seasons.It's on a random street far outside of where you'd expect to find amazing Chinese food in London (or anywhere for that matter) and the peking duck is the real showstopper. The pancakes are not as good as the actual duck but they are no slouch...some of the best i've ever had outside of the finest restaurants in China. The fried rice and other dishes aren't why you go here so don't even try them. Go here for the duck and make sure you make your pancakes properly with a bit of sauce on the pancake, and one piece of each of the garnishes, the way they do it in China, to get the most out of each bite.#2 on my list for Peking Duck behind Made in China Restaurant at the Grand Hyatt Beijing.

g-b_aDU6beLcbKGAYg3_Hw.text: I finally relented and made the pilgrimage to Bayswater and Four Seasons.  I'd been hearing about this place from friends, relatives and acquaintances...really anybody who'd spent any time at all in London.I was sick about hearing about how good the duck was and how there was no duck in Singapore like it.  I figured that this was a relative impossibility.  Also, I never actually thought that I'd actually go to a Chinese restaurant in London, one of the great restaurant towns, and in my book one of the greatest.    So I finally made a detour from my usual stop, St John and made the trek out to Bayswater.Ok.  It's all true.  The duck is good, "to die for" good.  The skin is crispy, the meat tender and layered with fat?  How is this possible, marbling on duck flesh??  I am unimpressed by duck.  It'll have to be a goose and then roasted and sampled fresh from the chopping block in Kowloon before I have anything worthwhile to say...ok, so I'm a roast fowl snob. Why cannot meh?  But the duck at Four Seasons made me want to use words and lyrics that I reserve for pork belly.  I actually closed my eyes, I'm ashamed to say...for duck??  But it is that good.  Four Seasons is crowded and the service brusque.  As I've said time and time before, ambience is entirely irrelevant if you came out for the food, because only the food matters.  And yes, Four Seasons could afford to be more of a pit and a dive, staffed by harridans and lepers and I'd still be a devotee.

photos.caption: Photo of Four Seasons - London, United Kingdom. How can you serve fresh cut chili and be evil?
Photo of Four Seasons - London, United Kingdom. The Duck...again
Photo of Four Seasons - London, United Kingdom. The Duck

SMNTa-rWuafPJaTZZ_CnUw.text: I absolutely enjoyed this place. The lot of us ordered half a pecking duck, mapo tofu, spinach and prawn dumplings to share. The duck was solidly done with the perfectly light pancakes and rich plum sauce to go with. I loved the mapo tofu as well -- adequately spicy and flavourful. The dumplings and spinach were some of the best I had in London. The reason why it's four and not five stars is really the service. I felt like they were inattentive to their customers, and they didn't even let us sit at our table till all five of us had arrived. Ambience is very casual and typical Chinese. Hence, not the place if you're looking for a posh Chinese experience. I'd definitely go back for my Chinese cravings!

n4Bhan9dSfpQBpoKJ8dGQw.text: One of the very many Soho Chinese restaurants on Gerrard Street. This is one of the smaller, less showy ones. It offers decent, though by no means spectacular food at competitive prices. Service is fairly efficient and, also, friendlier than usual in this area. But, then, as a frequent visitor to Chinese restaurants, you don't expect too much in terms of courtesy.When I ate there I tried three different dishes, all mains (Don't order rice at any of these places, it's a rip off and will only keep from eating enough of the *real* food): Cooked chicken with ginger (on the bone!), a mix of three types of grilled meat, and king prawns. See my photos.Everything was okay, nothing was outstanding. But in all fairness, the prices were on the lower end of Gerrard Street. After all, this is tourist area. When I was there, most of the other visitors were Chinese (might still be tourists of course). The decor isn't much to write home about, and because it tends to be busy, it may not be the best place to linger when you're  a couple or a group. Drinks selection, as usual, is rudimentary. I would recommend Chinese tea over inflated alcoholic drinks like Tsing Tao. There are plenty of good pubs near Leicester Sqaure for a beer after the meal.

photos.caption: Photo of Four Seasons - London, United Kingdom. King prawns.
Photo of Four Seasons - London, United Kingdom. Three types of grilled meat.
Photo of Four Seasons - London, United Kingdom. Cooked chicken with ginger, on the bone(!).

9gad2GYh9x0fLboQ9VI0nw.text: I was the only white person in there, which was totally fine except it made my service slow. Not sure it was color or I was solo. Either way wait service wasn't great. Ordered the pineapple duck and was not disappointed. I know I wouldn't finish a half let alone a quarter Peking duck so I opted for this. Side of rice cost extra. About 2.50£ Not what I wanted to spend, but it was good none the less. I probably won't go back, but it was a decent meal.

B1SF0Md575efGnbB0zunHA.text: Busy restaurant.  Pretty efficient. The roast duck is good albeit more sweet than I would like to have, but 3 of us finished a plateful of duck anyway. The stirred fried vegetable with chopped garlic was crispy and very delicious.  The only letdown was the ginger- onion Prawn.  It was salty and the prawn was pre-treated with Soda powder to make it crispy, which left an undesirable taste.  WE enjoyed our Dinner there and next time in town I would go there again.

1yPC-8N85VFPA82f1Ci7lQ.text: My boyfriend and I dropped by for dinner. The food was delicious! We had the rice with three types of meat. The BBQ pork and duck were amazing. We also ordered a stir fry prawns with vegetables and a sautéed spinach. The sauté spinach was done with eggs and century egg! Haven't had that in a long time! What a interesting street with tons of options from all over the world.

RBWjmv5Xt-YjivyFbgKxpQ.text: I don't know why people keep referring to the Four Season as the best duck Cantonese or other. Clearly they have not eaten anywhere else because it is defenerly not the best duck ever as some say. About 15 years or so ago there was an article I think in the evening standard by one of the food critics stating that the best Cantonese duck in town was to be found at the Four Season. Well let me tell you that I ate duck at the Four Season for several years before anyone ever raved about "The Duck". And I stopped eating there several years ago as I found that the "Famous Duck" was not so good. Now I understand the whaho of every one but I can eat a better duck at Canton China Town. And it cost less. I am writing this review because as I said after several years of been a patron of FS today I returned to see if it was better. NO NO NO it was even worst than I remembered. And please do not talk about service here. There is none. In all do go there but I would lower my expectations if I were you unless you don't know your duck from a chicken

JnvUZRM2rv2mWFRF5Ixlaw.text: When it comes to authentic Chinese food, here is your place to go. I came here with some friends to have some duck and oh man, was it good. We ordered a full duck sized portion for 3 people with pancakes and oh boy we were surprised that we finished it all. A friend of mine ordered the sweet and spicy soup - which was kind of mediocre on the verge of "um what is this??" It was alright, I wouldn't order that. The service was pretty poor. I mean we had to keep asking the waiter/waitress for certain things and they were really sloppy. When bringing our glasses of water, it dripped all over the table, and when they picked up our dishes, they were really messy.But if you don't mind the service, then this a good place to get good Chinese food.
